As the UN warns that trillions of dollars are being poured into activities that directly harm nature, prominent climate advocate Mary Robinson has called on governments to take science more seriously amid efforts to bring about nature-based solutions to the climate crisis.

The former Irish president was speaking in Dubai at the Cop28 climate summit during its themed "nature day" on Saturday, 9 December.

The UN Enviroment Programme chose the day to sound the alarm that investment in activities that promote a stable climate and healthy land was at least 30 times lower than investment in projects that are detrimental to nature.

Robinson – co-chair of the Elders group of former world leaders established by Nelson Mandela – said expertise on nature needed to be taken far more seriously by those in power.

"The Governments that did well in Covid listened to their chief medical officers … and took the tough decisions from the beginning," Robinson told a side event at Cop28.

"When I was president of Ireland from 1990-1997 I didn't make any speeches about climate. It was not an issue in Ireland at that time."

Carbon capture a 'dangerous excuse' for burning more fossil fuels
Climate justice

Robinson said it was only when she later became the UN's high commissioner for human rights did she understand the seriousness of the climate crisis – but she still wasn't clear on how it impacted her own work at the time.

"Another part of the UN was dealing with it [the issue of climate] and frankly I missed how important it was for my portfolio of human rights, gender equality rights of indigenous peoples and rights of people with a disability," Robinson said.

"It was when I started working in African countries in 2003, 2004 and 2005 – with a very small NGO – that I saw through the lens of human rights the impact of climate.

"And that brought me to climate justice – not climate change, but climate justice."

Feud over 'loss and damages' fund risks derailing climate talks
Adaptation deal

Robinson is among a chorus of voices at Cop28 pushing for a strong global goal on adaptation (GGA). The idea was established under the Paris Agreement in 2015 but has not yet been properly defined.

Unlike the 1.5°C temperature limit, it's less clear what an adaptation target would look like.

The GGA is being discussed as part of the summit's flagship global stocktake assessment, but progress has been slow on a fair and equitable finance agreement for climate adaptation.

"We're nowhere near where we should be on finance," Robinson warned.

"Money is going towards subsidising what's harming us ... rather than getting us back to a harmonious relationship with nature."

This too, she added, was a question of science.

"That's why we need a global adaptation target … because countries do not have the science."

urn:contentItem:6453-YVB1-JDH4-41MW-00000-00A prophetic challenge to rich nations, a call for climate justice2021-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:20:24ZLexisNexisA prophetic challenge to rich nations, a call for climate justice

Eye-witness reflection on the march in Glasgow during the recent COP26 climate change summit

Ever since reading Lorna Gold’s powerful Climate Generation: Awakening to Our Children’s Future(New City Press, 2019) I have been challenged by the poem "Hieroglyphic Stairway" by Drew Dellinger:

it’s 3:23 in the morning

and I’m awake

because my great great 

grandchildren

won’t let me sleep

my great great grandchildren

ask me in dreams

what did you do while the 

planet was plundered?

what did you do while the 

when the earth was unravelling?

surely you did something

when the seasons started failing?

as the mammals, reptiles, birds were all dying?

did you fill the streets with protest

when democracy was stolen?

what did you do

once

you

knew?

I have the words on a bookmark with photos of my six grandchildren. And my daughters used it on a banner they made for me.

For many of those who gathered in Glasgow for the UN Climate Change Conference, COP26 was a cathartic experience. There was a sense of having done something.

Done something in solidarity with an amazingly diverse group of people -- of all ages, genders, religious affiliations (and none), nationalities -- although everyone was conscious of the missing presence of many from the Global South.

In Glasgow I encountered many, many people who were seeking to live Gospel values - love of neighbour, especially the poor and marginalised, and love of Mother Earth.  

Some expressed this as a faith commitment but others, with no institutional religious affiliation, just saw it as the right thing to do.

It was so reminiscent of the situation during the height of the pandemic in Scotland: an unbelievable witnessing of love and sacrifice by so many, some with formal religious affiliation and many with none, whose actions were totally at one with the ushering in of that new world that Jesus proclaimed. 

They are that "new people for a new world" that the late Bishop Pedro Cassaldáliga, the Spanish Claretian Missionary to Brazil, spoke of. 

They are a manifestation of hope.

The Opening Ceremony was blessed by a moment of hope through the contribution of Elizabeth Wathuti from Kenya who described the reality of climate related starvation and asked if we had the "grace to fully listen" and the capacity to open our hearts and then act.

It was a call to conversion. 

The Youth March was another manifestation of hope - the young people's passion, creativity, knowledge, demands - all lifted your heart, and tears flowed as you sensed a new future may be possible if we would be daring enough and free ourselves from the economic and political structures that have led us to this climate emergency.

It was inspiring to see primary school children proudly affirming key aspects of the Scottish curriculum - they are responsible citizensand that is why they are on the streets.

Talking to them you realised the knowledge they had of the situation and of the changes needed to ensure climate justice for all.

Their chant -- "What do we want? Climate Justice! When do we want it? Now!" -- articulated so well their sense of urgency.

But sadly the "adults" at the "big table" did not seem to have that sense of urgency and it made you wonder what would the Gospel look like if COP26 had to sign off on it? 

The words of Rutilio Grande, the Jesuit martyred in 1977 in El Salvador, came to mind: "They will only leave us the covers because each of their pages is subversive."  

The story of the rich young man would be "wealth washed". 

They would not call him rich but rather "blessed with wealth". And he would not need to give up his wealth right away but could phase it over some indeterminate period and it would really be a loan.

A prophetic challenge to rich countries and to the Church came from Pastor Ray Minniecon, an Australian indigenous Anglican pastor, who urged us to address the impact of the Doctrine of Discovery on indigenous peoples throughout the world. 

What a statement the Church could make if it publicly apologized for the papal bulls that laid the foundation for the ruthless conquest and exploitation of indigenous people throughout the world. 

Pastor Ray also said any serious apology had to be based on Zacchaeus' principle -- "if you harm somebody you will recompense appropriately". 

The Church and all rich nations are required to look honestly at their history and enter into dialogue with those they have exploited. They must seek ways of finding forgiveness based on justice.

Whilst sharing the pain and anguish of indigenous people, Pastor Ray said that, despite the atrocities inflicted upon them, they still reached out the hand of friendship. 

It is a hand we must grasp. And we must do so now!

The people of Glasgow extended the hand of friendship to many. Through the “Homestay Network’ they opened their homes to climate activists from around the world. 

Marchers at COP26 boldly proclaimed the chant that will resonate through the streets of Glasgow for several years:  

“Say it loud, say it clear, refugees are welcome here!” 

That chant echoed through the Pollokshields area of Glasgow last May when a Home Office deportation raid in Kenmure Street was met with a sea of solidarity, which eventually led to the release of two men who had been detained in a police van.

All of Scotland, like Glasgow, has a proud history of welcoming refugees and asylum seekers. It rejects the attempt to create a "hostile environment" for our sisters and brothers who want to live their life in our country.

Climate justice is a Gospel imperative. And we are called to stand in solidarity with all those whose values and actions are in harmony with the dream and mission of Jesus by becoming a new people for a new world. 

Rab Burnett is a Laudato si' animator in Glasgow and an adviser for "Care of Creation Office"of the Bishops' Conference of Scotland. He is also a member of the core group of the Scottish Laity Network.
